Rev. Marek Vácha, chaplain of the University of Prague, celebrated the Eucharist on January 29 in a bar in Břevnov, Czech Republic. There were half-filled wine and beer glasses on the tables.
The celebration was called "The Lord in the Tavern.
An advertisement shared on social media announced a "pub party for believers and non-believers." It added that a waitress would be at the bar: "It will be possible to drink beer or other liquids throughout the evening."
The Bishops' Conference of the Czech Republic called the event "unlawful and inappropriate.
In a Feb. 3 statement, the bishops point out that the Eucharist "must be celebrated in a sacred place, unless in exceptional cases necessity requires otherwise." "The celebration of Holy Mass in a bar without serious reason is in itself inappropriate."
And: "In no case should the celebration of Holy Mass be combined with the context of an ordinary dinner.

FEBRUARY 19
SAN ÁLVARO DE CÓRDOBA
DOMINICAN (1358-1430)
High summit of the Hispanic and European spiritual magisterium, coat of arms of the Dominican Order, prez of Spain and emule of San Vicente Ferrer, Álvaro de Córdoba comes to the world in a random century, corroded by vices, stirred in chisms, hot struggle, to be an apostle of Truth and prince of Concord. Already at the dawn of his existence he appears wrapped in that divine nimbo that many will see shine around him in the crucial moments of his life.
He was born into a family of rich men and gentlemen in 1358. Don Martín López de Córdoba was Master of Calatrava and Alcántara, and Doña Sancha Alfonso Carrillo belonged to a lineage no less illustrious. The dreams of both went after the future knight who would green the laurels conquered by their elders in a secular struggle against morisma. But these dreams were truncated by Heaven to channel its chosen one on the path of a more exalted and heroic mission, in the purest conjunction …
